Ask yourself why Erdogan is interfering in the corruption investigation. The answer is quite simple: because he and his party have been illegally enriching themselves at the expense of the Turkish people, and he does not want the investigators to dig any deeper. The investigation has already tied the families of several ministers to the corruption, and it is likely only a matter of time before Erdogan and his family are implicated. It is an observable fact that several AKP politicians with very close ties to Erdogan have already been exposed as crooks. Thus, it is not libel or defamation.

I don't think A.K.P will lost Istanbul. I don't know why but some media channels use excessive defamation against Erdogan. Yes there is a corruption investigation in Turkey right now but this investigation has not been finished yet but some newspaper has already started to blame Erdogan and his government. We should answer some question before we judge Erdogan. For example, if there was a corruption, why the judiciary has  started this investigation just after Erdogan's act against Mr. Gulen? there was no corruption before that time? or some people try to threat Erdogan because of his act against the Gulen movement? We should consider these questions before we judge Turkey's prime minister. Some newspaper is blaming him with being a dictator. True awakenings tend to happen only after both sides are exhausted from continual warfare. The Catholic-Protestant live and let live agreement in continental Europe came after almost 150 years of war. There are parts of Germany that to this day have fewer people than they did before the 30 Years War began in 1618.

Even that change in attitude was very strongly influenced by the fact that the Ottoman Turks were knocking on the gates of Vienna, Krakow, and Venice.

But Catholic-Protestant battles continued in the British Isles until 1999, and the Protestant paramilitary forces still have not given up all of their weapons.

Every American and certainly every Marine should read "War is a Racket" written by Smedley Darlington Butler, a Marine Corps Major General and the most decorated Marine in history at the time of his death in 1940, with two Medal of Honor decorations in separate actions. He wrote it when he retired in the 1930's. I don't agree with his core intent as it is a polemic against the coming WWII, formed out of his long service in WWI and the various "banana wars" in Haiti, the Philippines, etc., but what he has to say about the use of the military by the corporate interests controlling the political establishments is 100% relevant today.

BTW, he never lost faith with the Corps - he loved the Corps always. It was the way the Corps and military was abused that he hated.

The Falluja Marines can be very proud of their service. They performed their duties in the very best traditions of the Corps.
Iraqi lives were wasted too, and many more of them. That for me is the real tragedy here and one Americans still decline to face.

To their credit, the vets care. But we cannot believe we can change a culture far removed from our own through force. Our armed forces were used for political motives and they did their job loyally. The truth remains Saddam was not a risk to our national security and US lives were wasted.

The war over poverty will remain an abstraction unless addressed in the context of the corrupting role big money plays in governance and in the context of the stifling grip lobbyists have on the executive and legislative branches of government.

In the aftermath of Citizens United, we are now close to a point where only the wealthiest can afford to run for public office. We are also at a point where lobbying, which is protected by the First Amendment of the US Constitution, is furthered by huge sums of money from special interest groups and industries, rendering it an abuse of the First Amendment.

When only the richest people govern, resulting in a more plutocratic than democratic form of government, equality vanishes. A class cast of the very rich emerges at the expense of a defenseless very poor class.

And when the abuse of the First Amendment, in the form of legalized bribery with the intent to influence legislation and or government policy results in favoring the very rich, the very poor remain helpless.

It would therefore seem that unless the role of big money and lobbying are addressed seriously, the so-called war over poverty will remain ineffective and meaningless.

That the war on poverty is a more successful string of battles as shown by much accumulated evidence, but the enemy is harassing us even with their dwindling.
Take Sen. Rubio's EITC nonsense as a point in case. There never ending stream of lies are used to promote ignorance. But much of the trouble is the term war is so disagreeable in an endeavor to help people that it should dropped along with other meaningless cliches. Bumper sticker don't vote and ignorance is the crux of the poverty issue.
The great battle is as Dr. Krugman suggests repeatedly a fight for equality. The way to win it is through grassroots education. They can have all the bumper stickers an TV advertising lies that tax cuts can buy. But if people follow nugget of US Grant's logic and hit them were they aren't. The battle against poverty and the ignorance that leads to it's continuation can be won, in a flanking around their big money campaigns and false equivalences. In our homes, offices, coffee houses and our many tables, educate your friends and neighbors to go vote against supply side economics and those that support the trickle down bunk.

Someone needs to step up first, and it ain't the poor.

Prof. Swagel was part of the Bush administration that had no problem using taxpayer money to bail out too-big-to-fail financial institutions that were major players in causing the mess we're still in, in amounts several orders-of-magnitude larger than the cost of the proposal that Mr. DeMarco vetoed; but like most conservative economists he draws the line at the potential for "moral hazard" in helping out ordinary Americans victimized by the forces unleashed by the fat cats that Prof. Swagel's compatriots saved.

Not only is this heartless, but it makes no economic sense. When a responsible homeowner finds him/herself seriously underwater, through no fault of their own and due to economic circumstances beyond their control, writing down a portion of their mortgage principal is a far better alternative for all concerned than forcing them into foreclosure, resulting in greater losses to the lender, depressing neighboring property values and devastating the personal lives of families. There was a time, before our financial sector became nothing more than a giant casino in which only the little guys were allowed to be the losers, that this was understood in America.

What can a country do when the party that once worked for working people has been pulled in the direction of the elite? Clinton signed Nafta, cut welfare and repealed crucial bank regulations.

All this advanced the US on the road to middle class insecurity, more poverty, loss of jobs, and toward the 08 crash. The Bush era's tax cuts and support for financial lawlessness finished the process.

I am glad that both of these stories have become public. As a provider in the medical field I have seen this same situation many times.  What it brings to my mind is the subject of Death. The definition of death is: Death is the cessation of all biological functions that sustain a living organism.  Death is in and apart of all things. We are all heading toward death today.  What have we done to prepare for that moment? Have you told your loved ones how you want to die? Do you discuss what the meaning of "life" is to you and to others? We daily participate in the miracle of life beginning. Have you spent time thinking about the end of your life, your parents, your friends or your children?  i think we as a society could spend more time preparing and accepting death as a part of life.  And in that place......death would not look like either of these two situations.....very sad and painful.

I have read that brain dead patients can be kept "warm" for weeks, months, and sometime even up to a year based on various conditions such as the health of the patient, the severity of the treatment, and to some extent luck. I have also read that it is possible to carry a pregnancy in that stage.

Now in a thought experiment, let's say a deceased husband has frozen his sperm, giving his then surviving wife the full rights to it, and the wife is in the process of trying to get pregnant with that sperm. After a failed attempt she becomes brain dead due to an unrelated accident, but has a clear legally sound health directive that she wants the process to continue even if there is a small chance. Money is not an issue, and the close kins are also completely agreeable to an aggressive medical intervention.

In effect, the conception itself would take place after both the parents are legally deceased -- without any surrogate mother!

What are the legal, ethical, and moral implications. Is this even theoretically possible? If so, it is going to be only a matter of time before some case likes this comes up.

We already have all the pieces of this puzzle happening in parts. So this is not as much a giant leap but merely a specific sequence of somewhat low probability events.

Is the body decaying? I didn't think that is even possible as long as the patient is on life support.

I think the hospital would not be in this position if they had just given the mother a day or 2 to grieve and come to grips with it, instead of demanding that a bed be freed up immediately for another patient. They pushed a grieving person and when people are pushed, they push back!

Sarah and Tulip -- you are both doctors, big deal. The problem is, the doctors involved in these situations don't understand their limited role here. They work for the patient. They don't get to make these decisions, no matter the "science" involved. When the patient can't make decisions, family members make those decisions for them. Period. These arguments, however persuasive, should have been made to the FAMILY, for the FAMILY'S decision.

This is a question of law, not medicine. The question is, who makes these decisions. The answer is, the FAMILY, not doctors.

Well, it helps when the patient is 92.

Expecting loved ones to gracefully accept the death of someone 30, 50 or 70 years younger than that is a bit much.

That said, I am appalled by the horror show that the two cases outlined in this article have become. The state-mandated veneration of the fetus in Texas, and the pandering to the ignorance of the child's family, are both sickening situations that really reflect ill on our present political climate.

I've been following the Jahi McMath case for several weeks now, and it is appalling to me that the situation has gotten this far. As a medical professional myself, I didn't think that there would be any doctor out there who would willingly perform a tracheostomy and G-tube procedure on what is now a decaying body. The harm in these interventions is that the family gets a false sense of hope when there is none. I think these interventions, however, are mainly therapeutic for the mother- it is hard to blame her, as this is a tragic outcome to a routine surgery.

I guess the lesson that we all must think about is when to let go gracefully, which is much easier said than done. I will never forget being an intern in my first month of residency training. I was taking care of a 92 year old man who had developed a pneumonia and was in the ICU because of it. The daughters had flown in from all across the US to spend their last few days with their dad when it became apparent that he wouldn't survive this infection. When I walked into the ICU room to explain what would happen when we removed the breathing tube, the daughters and the patient's wife all looked at me and smiled. One of them, very calmly, said, "We are ready."

The grace and strength with which she told me this has been INDELIBLE in my mind- I will never forget it and can only hope that one day, when I too will have to deal with the death of my loved ones, that I can also let go with grace and dignity.

I don't recall that the military was very excited to go into that war. They were already stretched thin with Afghanistan and all their other commitments. The Bush WH had to force Gen Shinseki into retirement to do it.
Can you imagine how many officers got promoted or earned medals for brief stays in Iraq? The old adage "War is too important to be left to the Generals" is so true.

The public did have an opportunity to vote on the war. As I remember, the Battle of Fallujah took place in two parts. Early in Spring 2004 the first Battle of Fallujah had begun. But it was proving to be a difficult battle; one best postponed until after the 2004 presidential elections. The second Battle of Fallujah occurred after the 2004 elections in November 2004. That was the more hard fought battle.
It's funny that any troops would blame "the public" for sending them over. I don't recall when the public got to vote on the war. I do recall Bush and the military being very excited about it.
